transcript.text: ** Emily

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Angela

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Hi Angela, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Emily, and I'm with iRobot. We really appreciate you sharing your experience with the Roomba 694 in your online review, and we'd love to delve a little deeper into your feedback. I know the review was written a little while ago, when you were in college, but we’re keen to understand your full journey with the product, even up to now if you still use it. How are you doing today?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Hi Emily, I'm doing well, thanks for asking. Happy to chat. Yeah, that review was definitely from my college days, feels like a lifetime ago sometimes! But the core issues, you know, they really stuck with me.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** I completely understand. It's really valuable for us to hear how those experiences resonate over time. So, Angela, let's start at the beginning. In your review, you mentioned buying the Roomba 694 with a mix of excitement and skepticism. Could you tell me a bit more about what specifically motivated that purchase decision at the time, and what you were really hoping the Roomba would solve for you and your roommates?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Hmm, well, at the time, living in that apartment with two other people, it was just… chaotic, mess-wise. We had classes, jobs, social lives, and honestly, vacuuming was always at the bottom of the list. We had a cheap stick vacuum, but it was rarely used. Dust bunnies the size of small animals, crumbs everywhere after a Netflix binge… you get the picture. So, the idea of a robot, you know, just taking care of that daily grime, especially for the hard floors, sounded like a dream. It felt like it could actually make our apartment *feel* cleaner without any effort from us. That was the big draw. And the 694 was, I think, a more affordable option at the time, which was a huge factor for a college student.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. The promise of autonomous cleaning in a busy, shared environment is definitely appealing. You mentioned it was a more affordable option – did you consider any other brands or models before settling on the 694, or was Roomba just the name that came to mind for robot vacuums?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Oh, for sure. We looked around a bit online, mostly Amazon reviews, you know? There were some cheaper brands, but Roomba felt like the trusted name, the original. And then there were the really high-end ones with the mapping, but those were totally out of our budget. The 694 seemed like a good middle ground – it had the Wi-Fi, the app scheduling, so it felt "smart" enough for what we needed, without breaking the bank. It was that balance of features and price that sealed the deal, honestly.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Got it. So, a known brand, and a perceived sweet spot for features and budget. Now, let's talk about the experience once you had it. You did mention some positives – specifically, that when it *did* manage to complete a run, the cleaning performance on hard floors was surprisingly decent for daily maintenance, and the auto-schedule feature via the app was genuinely useful. Could you elaborate on those aspects? What did "decent" cleaning look like, and how did that auto-schedule feature fit into your daily life?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Yeah, definitely. When it worked, it actually *worked*. On the linoleum and the hardwood, it would pick up, like, all the surface stuff – hair, dust, those annoying little crumbs from cereal or snacks. It wasn’t a deep clean, no, but it kept things from looking perpetually dirty. And that was a win. The auto-schedule feature was probably my favorite part, hands down. We’d set it to run every weekday around 11 AM, when all three of us were usually out for classes or our part-time jobs. Coming home to floors that looked noticeably tidier, even if not perfect, it genuinely made a difference in how the apartment felt. It reduced that mental load of "ugh, the floors are gross again." So, that part was fantastic.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That sounds like it really delivered on the convenience aspect for those specific tasks. On the flip side, your review highlighted some significant frustrations, with navigation being the primary issue. You described it as "random bump and go" and "like a blindfolded toddler playing pinball." Could you give me a more vivid example of what that looked like in practice? How often would you find areas completely missed?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Oh, gosh, Emily. It was almost every single time. Seriously. We’d set it to run, and come home, and maybe one bedroom would be spotless – like, impeccably clean – and then the living room, which is where we spent most of our time, would still have food crumbs, dust, everything. Or it would clean the kitchen five times, but ignore the hallway leading to the bedrooms entirely. There was no logic to it. You’d watch it just randomly bounce off walls, turn, bounce off another, and you’re just thinking, "Why are you cleaning that same spot again when there's a huge patch of floor right there you haven't touched?" It was just so… inefficient. It felt like it was doing a lot of *work* but not actually *cleaning* the whole space effectively.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That sounds incredibly frustrating and certainly defeats the purpose of an autonomous cleaner. And following directly from that, the "getting stuck" problem seemed to be another major pain point. You mentioned it often required a "search-and-rescue mission." What were the most common culprits for it getting stuck? Were there specific areas or types of items that were just magnets for trouble?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** *[Sighs]* Yeah, the stuck problem. That was probably the biggest time-suck, actually. It was usually cables – phone chargers, laptop cords, even sometimes the power strip for the TV. We tried our best to hide them, tuck them away, but the Roomba always found a way. It would just get tangled, the brushes would stop, and then it would emit that sad, forlorn beep until one of us found it. And then, the other big one was under furniture. We had a low-slung couch, and it would consistently try to climb under it, get wedged, and just get stuck. Or, sometimes, it would try to climb over a shoe, or a backpack left on the floor, and just get high-centered. It happened, I'd say, at least once per cleaning cycle, if not more. We’d get the app notification, which was helpful, but then you’re still stopping whatever you're doing to go rescue your robot vacuum. It felt like it needed more babysitting than it was worth sometimes.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** So, it sounds like instead of truly hands-free, it became more of an "on-call" situation for intervention. Beyond the navigation and getting stuck, you also briefly touched on flaky Wi-Fi connectivity and average battery life. Can you tell me more about how those issues impacted your overall experience?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** The Wi-Fi thing was just a nuisance, really. The initial setup was fine, but then maybe once every couple of weeks, or sometimes more often, I'd open the app and it just wouldn't connect. It would say the Roomba was offline. And the only way to fix it was a full reset, unplugging it, holding down buttons, then going through the re-pairing process with the app. It wasn't hard, but it was just one more thing you had to do that made it feel less autonomous, you know? As for battery life, for our two-bedroom apartment, it usually managed to clean about two-thirds of it before needing to recharge. Which meant if it *didn't* get stuck, it would still sometimes die in the middle of a room, nowhere near its base. So, then you'd have to physically pick it up and put it on the charger. For a bigger house, I can't imagine how annoying that would be.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** It really adds up, all those small frustrations diminishing the overall convenience. Thinking back to before you got the Roomba, how were you and your roommates typically managing floor cleaning? And in hindsight, how did the Roomba 694 compare to your previous methods, in terms of effort and effectiveness, despite its flaws?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Before the Roomba, it was really just… sporadic manual vacuuming, maybe once a week, if we were motivated. Usually just the living room and kitchen, honestly. The bedrooms often got overlooked. So, in terms of *overall* cleanliness, the Roomba *did* help keep the daily dust and crumbs at bay, especially on the hard floors. It was a trade-off. We went from *rarely* vacuuming manually to *always* having some level of automated cleaning, but with the added "fun" of robot rescue missions and trying to predict where it might get stuck next. So, it was more consistent, but not truly "easier." It just shifted the type of effort required, I guess.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That's a great way to put it – shifting the type of effort. Now, Angela, your review concluded with the line, "For the price, I'd expect something a bit more self-sufficient." Considering your current situation – retired, with a higher income – how does that perception of the Roomba's value for money hold up today? Would your expectations for a "smart" vacuum be even higher now?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Oh, definitely. Much higher, actually. When I bought it, as a student, it felt like a significant purchase, but it was also, um, the best we could get for the budget at the time that felt reliable. Now, looking back, and thinking about what I'd be willing to spend, my expectations for true autonomy and intelligence are way, way up. I'd expect it to *actually* map my home, navigate logically, and avoid obstacles almost perfectly. The idea of a robot needing *my* intervention is just… it’s a non-starter now, given the price points of newer models and my current ability to afford them. The 694 felt like a basic tool that sometimes worked, not a smart home solution. So, for the price I paid then, it was "okay," but for what I'd expect to pay now for *any* robot vacuum, it would be a huge disappointment.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That's really insightful feedback, Angela, and it highlights how user expectations evolve with both technology and personal circumstances. If you could wave a magic wand and change three things about the Roomba 694 – or frankly, about robot vacuums in general based on your experience – what would be your top three improvement suggestions?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Okay, my top three. Number one, absolutely, hands down, *intelligent navigation*. It needs to map the space, understand where it's been, and plan its route efficiently. No more random pinball. That's paramount. Second would be vastly improved obstacle avoidance. It needs to *see* cords, shoes, low furniture, and just go around them, or stop, rather than getting tangled or stuck. It needs to be less, um, clumsy. And third, I'd say better battery life and charging intelligence. I want it to be able to clean a larger area, and reliably find its way back to its base every single time, without dying in a corner. Connectivity is a close fourth, but those first three are the core issues for me.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Those are very clear and actionable suggestions, Angela. Thank you. Building on that, based on everything you’ve shared – the good aspects, the significant frustrations, and your evolving expectations – how likely would you be to recommend the Roomba 694 specifically to a friend or family member today? And if you were in the market for a new robot vacuum, what would make you consider a different brand or model over a Roomba, or conversely, what would make you stick with us?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that's a tough one. Recommend the 694? Honestly, probably not, unless they were on a *super* tight budget and just wanted something for very light, superficial cleaning of hard floors in a completely minimalist, obstruction-free space. And even then, I'd give them a huge list of caveats about the navigation and getting stuck. As for what would make me switch… well, I think it comes back to those three points I just made. If a competitor offers truly superior intelligent mapping, impeccable obstacle avoidance, and robust battery life, *that* would be the deal-breaker for me. I'd need proof that it's actually *smart* and self-sufficient, not just automated. If Roomba had a model that clearly delivered on those points, and the reviews backed it up, I'd definitely consider staying with Roomba because of the brand recognition and past positive experience with the app and dustbin, but I would absolutely prioritize those functional improvements above loyalty.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That’s a very fair assessment, Angela. It sounds like the core promise of a robot vacuum – true autonomy – needs to be consistently met. To help us quantify your overall experience, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being extremely dissatisfied and 10 being extremely satisfied, what would be your overall satisfaction rating for the Roomba 694, reflecting on your entire period of ownership?

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** Oh, gosh. Uh… well, the positives were genuinely good when they happened, but the frustrations were so, so frequent. I’d have to say… probably a 4. Maybe a 4.5 if I'm being generous, mostly because of the brief moments of delight when it *did* clean well and I didn't have to think about it. But the constant intervention really drags that score down.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** A 4.5, understood. That gives us a clear picture. Angela, I really want to thank you again for your incredibly candid and detailed feedback. Your insights are invaluable as we continue to improve our products. This conversation has given us a much deeper understanding of the user experience with the 694, especially how those specific pain points truly impacted your daily life and expectations. We genuinely appreciate your time and honesty today.

transcript.speaker: **Angela
transcript.text: ** You're very welcome, Emily. I hope it helps. It's good to know my feedback is being heard.
